triples.name: Spontaneous symmetry breaking
triples.relevance: The paper studies continuous spontaneous symmetry breaking in the XY model, a fundamental concept in classifying phases of matter.

triples.name: Phase transition
triples.relevance: Phase transitions are central to understanding the behavior of matter and the paper demonstrates transitions between ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic phases.

triples.name: Goldstone boson
triples.relevance: Gapless Goldstone modes emerge from continuous symmetry breaking and control thermodynamic stability, which the paper explores experimentally.

triples.name: Classical XY model
triples.relevance: The paper realizes a two-dimensional dipolar XY model with continuous spin-rotational symmetry as its main physical system.

triples.name: Ferromagnetism
triples.relevance: The XY ferromagnet is one of the two phases demonstrated and characterized in the paper for its long-range order.

triples.name: Antiferromagnetism
triples.relevance: The XY antiferromagnet is the complementary phase to the ferromagnet, both prepared adiabatically in the Rydberg array.

triples.name: Quantum simulator
triples.relevance: The paper proposes and uses a programmable Rydberg quantum simulator to experimentally realize the two-dimensional XY model.

triples.name: Rydberg atom
triples.relevance: Rydberg atoms form the basis of the programmable quantum simulator used to create the dipolar XY model with long-range interactions.

triples.name: Dipole
triples.relevance: Long-range dipolar interactions are essential to the paper's realization of the XY model and enable long-range order without disorder.

triples.name: Long-range order
triples.relevance: The paper characterizes the presence of long-range XY order in the ferromagnetic phase, a feature prohibited without long-range dipolar interaction.

triples.name: Ising model
triples.relevance: The paper references the Ising model's discrete symmetry breaking as a contrast to the continuous symmetry breaking studied in the XY model.
